snippet: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether a high-speed police chase that results in accidental -- although perhaps foreseeable -- injury or death violates the Constitution.    A lawyer for a California sheriff's deputy first told the Just...
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether a high-speed police chase that results in accidental -- although perhaps foreseeable -- injury or death violates the Constitution. A lawyer for a California sheriff's deputy first told the Justices that only a chase so egregiously reckless as to ''shock the conscience'' could violate the constitutional guarantee of due process of law.
abstract: Supreme Court hears arguments on whether high-speed police chase that results in accidental--although perhaps foreseeable--injury or death violates Constitution; Terence J Cassidy, lawyer for California Sheriff's Deputy James E Smith, says Smith should be immune from damage suit brought by family of Philip Lewis, 16-year-old motorcycle passenger who died in 1990 when Smith's patrol car skidded into him after chasing motorcyle at speeds of up to 100 miles an hour (M)

headline.main: Court Considering Whether a Police Chase Violated Rights
